header.gameNote: PAC 10 TOURNAMENT AT SAN JOSE CA

article.description: Candace Wiggins made an impressive return to the lineup, scoring 16 points with four 3-pointers to lead the Cardinal (No. 8 ESPN/USA Today; No. 7 AP) past Arizona 65-55 Saturday night and into the Pac-10 tournament semifinals.
article.headline: Cardinal post ninth consecutive win over Wildcats
article.linkText: Wiggins' return spurs Stanford onto next round
article.story:
SAN JOSE, Calif. -- Candice Wiggins deemed herself healthy, forgot about her tender hamstring and let adrenaline carry her.

Stanford's star guard made an impressive return to the lineup, scoring 16 points with four 3-pointers to lead the Cardinal (No. 8 ESPN/USA Today; No. 7 AP) past Arizona 65-55 Saturday night and into the Pac-10 tournament semifinals.

The slow pace of the game was perfect for Wiggins, who missed the final two conference games with a hurt left hamstring and five total games with injuries. Coach Tara VanDerveer opted to start the two-time Pac-10 player of the year and monitor her closely -- because having her full strength for the NCAA Tournament is what matters most.

Wiggins played 35 minutes and hit back-to-back 3s to start an 8-2 spurt in the second half of Stanford's seventh straight win.

"A lot of people who have been injured, and this is a minor injury, in their lifetime know that you when you get back on the court it is so exciting and you really have a new appreciation for the game," Wiggins said. "That's how I was today."

The Cardinal beat the Wildcats for the ninth time in a row -- with eight of those being by double digits. And Stanford's six 3-pointers equaled the team's total from its previous four games combined.

The Cardinal (26-4) advanced to play in the second semifinal Sunday against Southern California, which beat Washington 81-77. Stanford is looking to win the championship again after losing 85-76 to UCLA in overtime last season to end the Cardinal's three-year run of conference tournament titles.

Pac-10 freshman of the year Jayne Appel added 18 points, 13 rebounds and three assists for Stanford -- and she scored five straight points during one second-half stretch. Jillian Harmon scored 10 of her 11 points in the opening 10 minutes and dished out five assists, while Brooke Smith had nine points, nine rebounds and six assists.

"We weren't consistent enough in the post to do much," Arizona coach Joan Bonvicini said. "Jayne does a great job of holding her defender off. She is dominating."

Ashley Whisonant scored 14 of her 18 points in the first half and Joy Hollingsworth added 14 points and six rebounds for the Wildcats, who appeared to get tired in the second half against the physical Cardinal. Whisonant, Arizona's gutsy junior guard, was chasing Wiggins around for much of the night and eventually fouled out.

Arizona (11-21) lost three of its last four Pac-10 games, but played ninth-ranked Arizona State tough in a 59-54 defeat Feb. 24 to end the conference season.

The Wildcats were reminded just how much better Stanford is with Wiggins on the floor. She brings enthusiasm on both ends of the court that her teammates feed off.

"Candice just brings so much energy," Harmon said.

Wiggins was thrilled to be back on the court, having looked in VanDerveer's eyes earlier and promised she was fine to play. Wiggins cheered loudly as she ran out during introductions with her hamstring wrapped. Afterward, she sprinted off the floor with her teammates running close behind.

Wiggins said warming up well before the game on the stationary bike was key.

"In that kind of situation for Candice, I don't even think she broke a sweat," VanDerveer said. "She probably could have played last weekend, but I thought it was a good situation to have her sit out and heal more and not have her re-injure anything."

Stanford, coming off its school-record seventh straight Pac-10 regular-season title, led by 14 points in the first half, but needed a strong showing over the final 20 minutes after allowing Arizona to get back in it.

The Wildcats started the game 3-for-14 and had a tough time getting anything going inside against the Cardinal's talented posts. Stanford made its first four 3-point attempts then missed seven straight during one stretch late in the half and was outscored 13-2 over the final 4:50 as the Wildcats pulled to 30-28 at the break.
